title: Hallowe'en and Bonfire Night call for easy food to eat outside – and this dish is the answer
text:
I don’t think I’m alone in feeling that Hallowe’en is now more celebrated than Bonfire Night and that this is due to the growing American influence on our culture. When I was young, Bonfire Night was the big occasion to look forward to at this time of year, while Hallowe’en went almost unnoticed. Every high street would have at least one gaggle of children demanding a “penny for the guy”, and we all learnt the rhyme encouraging us to “remember, remember the fifth of November; gunpowder, treason and plot”.

I was surprised, then, to discover how prominent an event Hallowe’en was at the time of the Gunpowder Plot in 1605. All Hallow’s Eve had been well celebrated back in the Middle Ages, as can be seen in the stained-glass windows of the “danse macabre” still visible in churches today. These skeletons “dancing” in the graveyard were the souls in purgatory awaiting their chance to ascend to heaven – a very Catholic concept that didn’t sit well after the Reformation in a country worried about attack from the powerful nations of Catholic Europe.

The Gunpowder Plot had only just been uncovered when a law was passed in Parliament which demanded that the people of England celebrate its failure. This was a great way to flush out more Catholics, since suspicions would be raised if you didn’t celebrate with everyone else. The law remained until it was repealed in 1859, and as a result the worryingly “Catholic” Hallowe’en was usurped as a seasonal celebration by the more suitably “Protestant” Bonfire Night.

In modern times both festivals can be considered part of a winter season of feasting – a concept which I really like, and first came across in Gizzi Erskine’s cookbook Season’s Eatings. Rather like the summer season of Wimbledon, Henley, Ascot and so on, this book offered recipe ideas for Hallowe’en, Bonfire Night, the build-up to Christmas, New Year celebrations and finally Twelfth Night.
